title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0001
text: Which package contains the SortedMap interface?
explanation: The SortedMap interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0002
text: Which interface does SortedMap extend?
explanation: The SortedMap interface extends the Map interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0003
text: What is the main characteristic of a SortedMap?

options.text: Keys are stored in ascending order
Keys are stored in insertion order
Keys are stored in reverse order only

explanation: A SortedMap stores keys in ascending order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0004
text: Which of the following classes implements the SortedMap interface?
explanation: TreeMap is the main implementation of the SortedMap interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and null keys?

options.text: TreeMap does not allow null keys

explanation: TreeMap does not allow null keys because it uses natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0006
text: Which of the following methods returns the first key in a SortedMap?
explanation: The firstKey() method returns the first (lowest) key in the SortedMap.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods returns the last key in a SortedMap?
explanation: The lastKey() method returns the last (highest) key in the SortedMap.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods returns a view of the portion of the map strictly less than a given key?
explanation: The headMap(K toKey) method returns a view of the portion of the map strictly less than the given key.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods returns a view of the portion of the map greater than or equal to a given key?
explanation: The tailMap(K fromKey) method returns a view of the portion of the map greater than or equal to the given key.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods returns a view of the portion of the map between two keys?
explanation: The subMap(K fromKey, K toKey) method returns a view of the portion of the map between two keys.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0011
text: Which of the following methods returns the comparator used to order the keys in a SortedMap?
explanation: The comparator() method returns the comparator used to order the keys in the map, or null if natural ordering is used.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and ordering?

options.text: SortedMap maintains keys in ascending order

explanation: SortedMap maintains keys in ascending order by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and duplicates?

options.text: SortedMap does not allow duplicate keys

explanation: SortedMap does not allow duplicate keys, but values can be duplicated.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and TreeMap?
explanation: TreeMap implements the SortedMap interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator?

options.text: A custom Comparator can define the sorting order
Comparator cannot be used with SortedMap
Comparator is used only for duplicates

explanation: A custom Comparator can be provided to define the sorting order of keys in a SortedMap.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and natural ordering?

options.text: If no comparator is provided, natural ordering is used
Natural ordering is used only for duplicates

explanation: If no comparator is provided, SortedMap uses the natural ordering of its keys.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and synchronization?

options.text: SortedMap is not synchronized by default

explanation: SortedMap is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedSortedMap().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0018
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a SortedMap?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedSortedMap() method returns a synchronized (thread-safe) sorted map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and immutability?

options.text: SortedMap can be made unmodifiable using Collections.unmodifiableSortedMap()

explanation: SortedMap can be made unmodifiable using the Collections.unmodifiableSortedMap() method.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and iteration order?

options.text: SortedMap iterates keys in ascending order
SortedMap iterates keys in insertion order
SortedMap iterates keys in reverse order only

explanation: SortedMap iterates keys in ascending order by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and descending order?

options.text: NavigableMap provides descendingMap() for reverse order

explanation: NavigableMap, a subinterface of SortedMap, provides descendingMap() for reverse order views.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator() method?

options.text: comparator() returns null if natural ordering is used
comparator() throws an exception if no comparator is set

explanation: If natural ordering is used, comparator() returns null.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and subMap()?

options.text: subMap() returns a view between two keys

explanation: The subMap() method returns a view of the portion of the map between two keys.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and headMap()?

options.text: headMap() returns entries with keys less than a given key
headMap() returns entries with keys greater than a given key

explanation: The headMap() method returns a view of entries with keys less than the specified key.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and tailMap()?

options.text: tailMap() returns entries with keys greater than or equal to a given key
tailMap() returns entries with keys less than a given key

explanation: The tailMap() method returns a view of entries with keys greater than or equal to the specified key.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and TreeMap performance?

options.text: TreeMap provides O(log n) performance for basic operations

explanation: TreeMap provides O(log n) performance for add, remove, and containsKey operations.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most SortedMap implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most SortedMap implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator usage?

options.text: Comparator defines custom sorting logic for keys

explanation: Comparator defines custom sorting logic for keys in a SortedMap.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares maps based on key-value pairs
equals() compares maps based on order
equals() compares maps based on references
equals() compares maps based on hash codes only

explanation: The equals() method compares maps based on their key-value pairs, not order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and hashCode()?

options.text: hashCode() is based on the key-value pairs
hashCode() is based only on keys

explanation: The hashCode() method of a SortedMap is based on its key-value pairs.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and null values?

options.text: TreeMap does not allow null values
TreeMap allows only one null value

explanation: TreeMap allows null values but not null keys.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and keySet()?

options.text: keySet() returns a SortedSet view of keys
keySet() returns a List view of keys
keySet() returns a Collection of values
keySet() returns a Map of keys

explanation: The keySet() method returns a SortedSet view of the keys contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and entrySet()?

options.text: entrySet() returns a Set view of key-value pairs
entrySet() returns a List view of keys
entrySet() returns a Collection of values
entrySet() returns a Map of entries

explanation: The entrySet() method returns a Set view of the key-value pairs contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and values()?

options.text: values() returns a Collection view of values
values() returns a Set view of values
values() returns a Map of values
values() returns a List of keys

explanation: The values() method returns a Collection view of the values contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and NavigableMap?

options.text: NavigableMap extends SortedMap with navigation methods
NavigableMap is a subtype of List

explanation: NavigableMap extends SortedMap and adds navigation methods like lowerKey(), higherKey(), and descendingMap().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and subMap() boundaries?

options.text: subMap() includes the lower bound and excludes the upper bound
subMap() includes only the upper bound

explanation: The subMap() method includes the lower bound and excludes the upper bound by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator chaining?

options.text: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria
Comparator chaining is used for synchronization

explanation: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria using methods like thenComparing().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and fail-fast iterators?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the map is modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator-based sorting?

options.text: Comparator defines custom sorting logic for keys

explanation: Comparator defines custom sorting logic for keys in a SortedMap.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and TreeMap synchronization?

options.text: TreeMap is not synchronized by default

explanation: TreeMap is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedSortedMap().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator() return value?

options.text: Returns null if natural ordering is used

explanation: If natural ordering is used, comparator() returns null.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and key uniqueness?
explanation: Keys in a SortedMap must be unique; duplicate keys overwrite existing entries.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and values duplication?
explanation: Values in a SortedMap can be duplicated, but keys must be unique.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and iteration order?
explanation: Iteration over a SortedMap follows ascending key order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator chaining?

options.text: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria
Comparator chaining is used for synchronization

explanation: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria using methods like thenComparing().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and NavigableMap methods?

options.text: NavigableMap adds methods like lowerKey() and higherKey()
NavigableMap is a subtype of List

explanation: NavigableMap extends SortedMap and adds navigation methods like lowerKey() and higherKey().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator chaining?

options.text: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria
Comparator chaining is used for synchronization

explanation: Comparator chaining allows multiple comparison criteria using methods like thenComparing().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and fail-fast iterators?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the map is modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about SortedMap and comparator() return value?

options.text: Returns null if natural ordering is used

explanation: If natural ordering is used, comparator() returns null.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSortedMap - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the SortedMap interface?

options.text: A map that maintains keys in ascending order
A map that maintains insertion order
A map that allows duplicate keys
A map that stores keys randomly

explanation: The SortedMap interface represents a map that maintains keys in ascending order.
